intro: Chailletia hirtella, commonly known as the hairy chailletia, is a species of flowering plant native to parts of South America. It belongs to the family Malvaceae, which includes cotton and hibiscus, and is characterized by its hairy stems and leaves. The plant typically grows in moist, shaded environments such as forest understories. Its flowers are small and clustered, often with five petals, and it produces capsule fruits that contain numerous seeds. Chailletia hirtella is of interest to botanists due to its unique morphology and ecological adaptations.
